title: Distinct LCM of Consecutive Integers
description: Is M(n,k) = lcm(n+1,...,n+k) always distinct for m ≥ n+k? The Thue–Siegel theorem gives finiteness for fixed k. Only two cross-parameter examples are known.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about the distinctness of lcm of consecutive integer blocks. The Thue–Siegel theorem implies finiteness for fixed k. Erdős knew only two cross-parameter examples: lcm(5,6,7) = lcm(14,15) = 210 and lcm(4,5,6,7) = lcm(20,21) = 420. A stronger conjecture asserts that consecutive products can rarely share the same prime factor set.
overview.problemStatement: Let M(n,k) = lcm(n+1,...,n+k). Is M(m,k) ≠ M(n,k) for all m ≥ n+k?
overview.proofStrategy: We define lcmInterval using Finset.fold with Nat.lcm, consecutiveProduct using Finset.prod, and samePrimeFactors via Nat.primeFactors. The main conjecture and its stronger variant are stated as Prop. Thue–Siegel finiteness is an axiom.
keyInsights: The Thue–Siegel theorem gives finiteness for fixed k but not the full conjecture
Only two known cross-parameter examples exist (both involving k=2 on one side)
The stronger prime-factor conjecture would imply the LCM conjecture
Related to Erdős Problems 678, 686, and 850 on consecutive products

sections.title: Basic Properties

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 677 on distinctness of LCM of consecutive integers, the stronger prime-factor conjecture, and Thue–Siegel finiteness. 0 sorries.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would advance understanding of multiplicative structure of consecutive integers and connect to Diophantine equations.
openQuestions: Is M(m,k) ≠ M(n,k) for all m ≥ n+k?
Are the two known cross-parameter examples the only ones?
Does the stronger prime-factor conjecture hold?
